title: Bride-to-be hanged herself after being haunted by crash that killed her friend
text:
Serena Williams was planning a family holiday to Gran Canaria when she took her own life (Photo: Cavendish Press) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A bride-to-be hanged herself after a long battle with depression that began after she survived a motorbike crash that left a friend dead 30 years ago. 
Mother-of-four Serena Williams was a teenage schoolgirl when the crash happened in 1987 and blamed herself for her friend's death. 
The 45-year-old was left seriously injured in the accident, which occurred when the friends were on their way home from school, and was told she would suffer from headaches for the rest of her life. 
Ms Williams had been due to marry and was planning a family holiday to Gran Canaria when her fiance found her dead last October 1, an inquest heard. Ms Williams and fiance Chris Thomas (Photo: Cavendish Press) 
Chris Thomas, 44, discovered her body after she committed suicide their home in Eccles, near Salford, Greater Manchester. Read More Mum's victory for severely ill son as she walks through customs at Dublin despite declaring she was carrying CANNABIS 
The caring nurse was described by family has having "everything to live for". 
The tragedy occurred after Ms Williams fought a long battle against depression during which she had twice tried to take her own life, the inquest in Bolton heard. 
Her mother, June Williams, said: “When Serena was 15, she was in a very serious motorbike accident. She was the passenger on the motorbike with her friend who was 18 and was giving her a lift from home. Ms Williams blamed herself for her friend's death, an inquest was told (Photo: Cavendish Press) 
“A car cut across their lane of traffic and Serena received a fractured skull and broken bones. Her friend who was driving didn’t survive the crash and Serena blamed herself for the death. 
“She was in hospital for two weeks and a psychiatrist told her she would most likely suffer from headaches for the rest of her life. It had a very bad effect on her mental health.'' 
Ms Williams pursued a career in nursing and worked both at a care home and at Salford Royal Hospital but she had two broken relationships in which she had a son and two daughters. 
She suffered from severe post-natal depression and on one occasion she tried to hang herself in a hospital psychiatric unit and then later took an overdose. The 45-year-old worked at a care home and Salford Royal Hospital (Photo: Cavendish Press) 
In July 2014, Ms Williams appeared to recover when she met Mr Thomas through work and they moved in together and she had a son by him in January 2016. Read More Schoolboy killed after being knocked over by minibus driven by his teacher 
Her mother added: ''She appeared to be coping well and she never spoke to us about any problems she was having - although when we went round we noticed she was lying on the sofa and was reluctant to get up. 
“I last saw her when I’d been looking after the baby whilst she was at work. She seemed her normal self and I left to go home and that was the last time I ever saw her. She had everything to live for and she loved taking her girls horse-riding and was planning her wedding to Chris in May. 
“She had a caring personality and loved all her children. We cannot explain why she did what she did. She was very depressed and we think she acted on the spur of the moment. She was making plans for the future.” Mr Thomas found his fiancee's body at their home (Photo: Cavendish Press) 
Mr Thomas told the hearing how his wife-to-be had been battling to get access to her two daughters. 
He added: “I have been with Serena since July 2014 and I was aware that before she met me she had problems with depression and had made attempts to take her life. Read More Horrifying Snapchat video shows woman set-upon by gang of teenage girls as witnesses filmed on phones 
''When our relationship began I did not believe she was taking any medication. Her only concern was access to her daughters. She was granted access, but it was a tiring and stressful process. 
“Sometimes she was positive about it but she didn’t like going to court and having her past bought up again. 
"Both sets of parents regularly helped with child care and she was positive about the future. The quality of time she was spending with the girls was improving.'' Ms Williams died after a long battle with depression (Photo: Cavendish Press) 
He said he last saw his fiancee when ho got home from work and they began discussing plans for the weekend. 
He went to bed only to find her body on the stairs when he woke up the following morning. 
Mr Thomas told the hearing ''She had got a bit upset about daughters but I calmed her down and told her we were making progress and we were talking about our plans to go to Gran Canaria. 
“I cannot think of anything she said or did that was out of the ordinary. I cannot say for certain if she wanted to her take own life. She not been under the care of the mental health services in recent years.'' 
Serena’s eldest son Saul Williams Wilson, a carer who lives in Brighton, said: “The last time we met she had told me that she had been anxious and sometimes wished she was not here. 
"She was sad about not spending time with her daughters and said she wished our relationship could have been better and didn’t want me to live so far away. The inquest heard Ms Williams "had everything to live for" (Photo: Cavendish Press) 
“She also told me she was overwhelmed with having another baby, I think she may have been suffering with post-natal depression again.” Read More 'Real-life Notebook' couple with dementia still deeply in love after 50 years - despite not always recognising each other 
Police examined Miss Williams' phone hand found a text sent to her brother which talked about her plans to go horse riding. 
Recording a narrative verdict, coroner Jennifer Leeming said: ''I do have concerns about her intentions. Serena took her own life at a time when her judgement was impaired, including by depressive illness and her intention if therefore unclear." 
She told the family: “Please accept my most sincere sympathy. You have lost a loving daughter, mother, sister and partner.”
